gift_source:
::MC1::
What does color constancy mean?
{
= Object color appears stable under different lighting
~ All colors are perceived equally
~ Shadows have no effect
~ Brightness never changes
}
title: MC1
question: What does color constancy mean?

choices.text: Object color appears stable under different lighting

gift_source:
::MC2::
Which is an example of a brightness illusion?
{
= Checker shadow illusion
~ Stereopsis
~ Motion parallax
~ Gamma correction
}
title: MC2
question: Which is an example of a brightness illusion?

gift_source:
::MC3::
Which explains why two squares of the same shade look different in context?
{
= Influence of surrounding shading and shadow
~ Incorrect sensor calibration
~ JPEG compression
~ File size differences
}
title: MC3
question: Which explains why two squares of the same shade look different in context?

choices.text: Influence of surrounding shading and shadow

gift_source:
::MC4::
Which is NOT a characteristic of human vision?
{
= Perfect measurement of absolute light intensity
~ Color constancy
~ Brightness constancy
~ Context-dependent perception
}
title: MC4
question: Which is NOT a characteristic of human vision?

choices.text: Perfect measurement of absolute light intensity

gift_source:
::MC5::
Why do illusions matter for computer vision?
{
= They reveal how human perception differs from raw data
~ They eliminate the need for sensors
~ They ensure all pixels are accurate
~ They prevent image compression
}
title: MC5
question: Why do illusions matter for computer vision?

choices.text: They reveal how human perception differs from raw data
They eliminate the need for sensors
They ensure all pixels are accurate

= Color constancy -> Stable object color under different lights

= Shape constancy -> Stable shape perception despite orientation
}
